section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Big Book: A Friend Like You

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: By Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen, illustrated by Sean Julian
section-block.rac_book_summary: Squirrel and the bird are very different. One of them eats nuts, and the other likes worms. The bird can fly, but Squirrel can only climb. Even so, they like being with each other and become the best of friends.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about friends. Discuss what they think makes someone a good friend. What do they do to be a good friend?
Invite children to sing “The More We Get Together.” Sing: “Your friends are my friends, and my friends are your friends. The more we get together, the happier we’ll be.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read A Friend Like You by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen and illustrated by Sean Julian.
Scout loves to read narratives. In this story, he will read about a squirrel just like him!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we finish the book. Ready?
What are some ways we can make new friends?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and use the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why do you think Squirrel was so busy in autumn? Why had he buried so many nuts?
What did Squirrel do to try to make friends with the bird?
Why do you think Squirrel asked the bird to come climbing with him?
Why do you think the bird asked Squirrel to sing with him?
Why do you think the bird is happy he met Squirrel?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What are some ways we can make new friends?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We can make a new friend by being nice.
We can make a new friend by helping someone.
We can make a new friend by spending time together.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about making friends as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can we make new friends?
We can make new friends by being n____ (nice) to each other.
We can make new friends by being nice to each other.
What is something youwould ask a new friend todo with you?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: As we read and reread wonderful books with children, we can look for layered learning opportunities. This book is about friendship, but it also includes valuable information about seasons, the needs of living things, migration, and more. As appropriate, consider diving deeper to follow children’s interests and spark a love of learning.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Play With Others
section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about how friends like to play together. Start a discussion about a time when they asked a new friend to play with them. What did they say to invite the friend to play? How about a time when they joined a group of children who were already playing? What did they say to the children? Did they have fun together?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book A Friend Like You by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen and illustrated by Sean Julian. We will look for ways that the two friends play together.
Clifford loves playing with his friends. He enjoys reading stories about making new friends and finding fun things to do together.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book and talk about how friends can learn to play together.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions during reading.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How did Squirrel and the bird play together in the tree? What made Squirrel very happy? What are “happy goosebumps”? (MB)
The bird wanted Squirrel to sing with him, but Squirrel didn’t know how. The bird had an idea. How did Squirrel join in? (MB)
If you played with Squirrel and the bird, what movements would you make? (MB)
Would you feel happy if you were Squirrel? Why?
Why do you think Squirrel wanted the bird to stay? Have you ever wanted a friend to stay longer? (MB)
Squirrel the bird had a plan to stay together. Did the bird and Squirrel reach their goal?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to do a Friendship Roll. Have all the children sit in a circle with you. Call a child’s name and roll the ball to that child. Then call out another name and have the child with the ball roll the ball to that person. As children roll the ball to a new person, invite them to call out, “I have a friend whose name is _____ .” Continue until all the children have had a couple of turns.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how friends play together.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Initiating and joining in play are key social development skills for young children. While playing, children learn important skills that they will continue to use for the rest of their lives: problem-solving, creativity, and a willingness to take risks, among others. Helping children learn the language for initiating and joining in play sets them up for success (Pathways.org/six stages).

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about a time they needed to listen and remember. How did it help them?
Invite children to listen and repeat after one child: “My name is ____ and I like to ____ . ” Continue with the next child, and so on.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit A Friend Like You by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen and illustrated by Sean Julian.
Scout knows that it’s important to listen to your friends. He wants to listen to what Squirrel and the bird say to each other.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we finish the book. Ready?
What are some things that Squirrel and the bird like to do together?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and use the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why was the bird surprised to find out that nuts are delicious? What does the bird usually eat?
Squirrel likes to climb. What does the bird like to do?
Sometimes friends like to do different things. The bird likes to sing. What does Squirrel do with his new friend?
What did Squirrel and the bird do together all day long? Do you think they did things exactly the same way? Why?
Have you ever had happy goosebumps like Squirrel has? What fun things do you do together with your friends? (MB)
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? Let’s see how much you remember as we turn and talk about the guiding question:
What are some things that Squirrel and the Bird like to do together?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you work together to write about things friends like to do.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is one thing they like to do together?
How do you and your friends like to play together?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Words that share the same morphology or root are known as cognates. For example, the English word delicious and the Spanish word delicioso are cognates. Giving multilingual learners the opportunity to recognize and talk about cognates helps strengthen their skills in both languages.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion of all they have learned about friends so far this week. What have they learned that they did not know before?
Sing a song to the tune of “Mary Had a Little Lamb.” Sing: “Will you meet a friend of mine, friend of mine, friend of mine? This is my friend ____.” Sing each child’s name.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Thank You, Friend! It is an informational text with an email and pictures of good friends.
Scout enjoys reading real emails and looking at pictures of good friends.
A Friend Like You and Thank You, Friend! both focus on ways to be a good friend. Let’s look at some connections between the two.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show A Friend Like You book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, think about this week’s concept question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the Big Chart, then use the following prompts to discuss it.
Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Good friends like to do things together.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the picture of the two boys with stars on their shirts? What are the boys doing in this picture? What are some of the things Squirrel and the bird did together in A Friend Like You?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Good friends share and take turns.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the picture of the children at the swing set? Why do you think the boy is standing behind the swing holding onto the chain?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Good friends do nice things for each other.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What are the two friends giving to each other? Do you think they are having fun? Why?

section.rac_body-text: Help children make a “Helping Hands of Friendship” bulletin board. Trace each child’s handprint on a colorful piece of paper and help them cut it out. Ask them to write their name on the handprint with a marker. Arrange the hands in a circle on the bulletin board. Children can then dictate to you one way they helped a friend so you can write it on the board under their handprint.
Provide a writing prompt about making friends and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: It’s important for young children to feel secure, valued, and cared about. Focusing their attention on how friendships develop among fictional characters as well as in their actual lives will play a vital role during this critical period of social-emotional growth.

section-block.rac_body-text: Start circle time by having children move around the circle greeting each other. Demonstrate first with a child. Make sure you make eye contact, shake that person’s hand, and greet them by name. If you like, you can also have them say one compliment to each of their friends.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book A Friend Like You, by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen and illustrated by Sean Julian.

This book is a narrative. Narrative means it is a story that the authors made up. Sometimes authors use animals as characters. Scout loves to read stories like this, especially since it stars a squirrel!
This week we read about the friendship between Squirrel and the bird. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
What do you think is the most important thing about being a good friend?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Imagine you helped Squirrel to bury nuts. Show me how tired you would be after working so hard.
Can you fluff your feathers and hop from foot to foot like the bird did when he tasted the delicious nut?
Would you rather climb or fly to the top of the tree? Show me how you would move.
Would you rather sing or hum? Let me hear you.
Squirrel and the bird decided to stay together even though they are very different. Do you think good friends can be very different from each other? Why?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What do you think is the most important thing about being a good friend?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Good friends like to spend time together.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about being a good friend and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do good friends tell each other?
Good friends tell each other how they are f__________ (feeling).
Good friends tell each other how they are feeling.
What would you like to say to your good friend?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children should spend hours every day in active play to help them develop strong bodies. Encourage children to move their bodies as much as they can as they learn about friendship, using both larger movements as they interact with other children as well as smaller movements during read alouds, songs, and indoor activities.
